book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship
author: K. Martens
key_insight: An iron rule: if variant A is with the odds but does not take you home, try variant B
solution_line: Win ace of hearts, play a spade to the king - to make this contract you need to find ace of spades with South. If he holds queen instead, he will overruff a fourth round of hearts
result_comparison: Closed Room Contract 3♠, +140 for Ukraine vs spade to king +620 = +10 IMP, spade to jack -6 IMP
additional_notes: West is declarer on all boards. You opened 1♠, North bid 2♥.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Calculate whether or not to win the first trick - consider all variants for kings placement. a) Both kings are offside – maybe the defenders’ hearts are blocked. b) Both kings are onside but there is a catch. c) The king of diamonds is offside and the king of spades onside. d) The king of diamonds is onside and the king of spades offside. In variant a) you should win the first heart. Maybe the hearts are: N: ♥ K 9 7 6 5 — S: ♥ Q 10? In variant b) your decision in hearts is immaterial. In variant c) it is essential to win the first trick. In variant d) winning the first heart trick may be damaging if the king of diamonds is fourth with South.
solution_line: Win with ace of hearts, overtake queen of spades with ace in dummy. Spade manoeuvre useful if variant b) with K-x-x-x onside in diamonds. Creates additional entry to dummy for second diamond finesse
result_comparison: Closed Room Contract 3NT(E), lead ♠6, +690 for Ukraine vs overtook queen with ace +630 = -2 IMP, if not -13 IMP
additional_notes: Should you win first trick or duck? Four variants to consider based on kings placement. South plays the queen.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship
author: K. Martens
key_insight: The trump coup requires an accurate plan - need proper timing and entries
solution_line: Win diamond lead in hand. Cash A-K of trumps. North discards club in second trick. Play A-K and another heart, ruffing. Cross to Q♦ and discard club on established heart. Pitch K♦ on last heart and ruff a diamond. Cross with A♣ and execute trump coup. Holding 4-3-4-2 shape South may beat the contract by discarding two clubs on two hearts. With 4-3-3-3 or 4-3-2-4 South will be hopeless. b) Spades 3-2. Draw the trumps and ruff a heart. Hearts 4-2 – and the contract is home. Hearts 5-1 against five with North, you still can make it executing heart and club squeeze with North.Hearts 5-1 with five with South. Final four cards: cross to dummy with Q dia, puts criss-cross heart-club squeeze on South
result_comparison: Closed Room Contract 6♠, +980 for EW vs played as above +11 IMP, if not -14 IMP
additional_notes: Holding 4-3-4-2 shape South may beat contract by discarding two clubs on two hearts. With 4-3-3-3 or 4-3-2-4 South will be hopeless. Spades 3-2, draw trumps and ruff a heart.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship
author: K. Martens
main_technique: Look for alternate lines of play
key_insight: When the defenders prevent one line, look for another line - thin game contracts require careful play
solution_line: Win trump lead in hand and play a club. Win next trump in dummy and ruff a club. Enter dummy with A♥ and ruff a club. Play Q-K of hearts, ruff yet another club. Play a good heart, pitching a diamond
result_comparison: Closed Room Contract 3♠ +140 for EW vs played accurately +620 = +10 IMP, if not -6 IMP
additional_notes: Thin game contract and opponents do not help by leading a trump. Hearts break 3-3, spades 3-2 and clubs 4-3. Something must work when you play thin games.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship
author: K. Martens
key_insight: You must adapt your play to match the opponents' level - against weaker players consider the chance of them making a mistake
solution_line: Win heart lead with jack. Play a diamond - against strong players play low from dummy (only theoretical chance is singleton honour with South or AK bare). Against weaker players must decide if chance of mistake higher than tiny theoretical chance
result_comparison: Contract 3♦, +130 for Ukraine vs played in line with odds +660 = +11 IMP, relied on mistake -6 IMP
additional_notes: Even after diamond to queen, can still make at double-dummy by ducking a spade and end-playing West, but that is fantasy land.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship
author: K. Martens
key_insight: If you make a reconnaissance play you will set up a throw-in squeeze - assume 2-to-1 odds that Q♣ is with South
solution_line: Win ace of hearts keeping queen in dummy. Draw trumps in two rounds. Cash A-K of diamonds and shape of South hand is clear: 2-6-1-4. At first glance seems you can only make if Q♣ is in North's doubleton. Play club to jack and you will come to a 3-card ending: a heart to South's K completes your work!
result_comparison: Closed Room Ukrainians stopped in 4♠, +450 vs made the slam +11 IMP, if not -11 IMP
additional_notes: South opened weak 2♥. A heart to South's king completes your work. Making this assumption, throw-in squeeze will give you the contract.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship
author: K. Martens
opening_lead: ♠3. South wins with ♠10 and plays ♠K. North follows with ♠2.
main_technique: Get Opponents to do what you want
key_insight: If you are a good player, then everything you have to do you will do well. If you are a very good player, then everything you have to do the opponents will do for you
solution_line: Play three rounds of clubs, ending in dummy. Play a spade from dummy. Discard two hearts and a diamond from your hand on the spades and two hearts from dummy
result_comparison: Closed Room Contract 3NT, +630 for Ukraine vs played as above +600 = -1 IMP, if not -12 IMP
additional_notes: South wins with ♠10 and plays ♠K. North follows with ♠2. Opponents' good play will help you make the contract.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Replace a greater risk with a smaller risk - concede a trick to reduce overall risk
solution_line: Discard a diamond from dummy on third round of spades. South can overruff in spades but much less likely to overruff in diamonds. Concede a trick to A♦ and draw two rounds of trumps. Will only go down if you find South with three hearts to jack and only three diamonds
result_comparison: Contract 4♥, +620 for Ukraine vs discarded diamond on spade: no swing, if not -12 IMP
additional_notes: North opened weak 2♠. Replace greater risk with smaller risk.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Play according to the distribution - use proper sequence to determine layout
solution_line: Ruff ace of clubs. Play ace of diamonds - North does not follow suit. Play K♠ and spade to ace. Pitch spade to K♣ and ruff spade. Throw South on lead with trump - South does not follow suit. Play heart to ace. Discard two hearts on two clubs and ruff heart. Cross to dummy with A♠ and ruff club. Play trump
result_comparison: Closed Room Contract 3NT (E), +430 for Ukraine vs made the slam +10 IMP, lost -10 IMP
additional_notes: Complex sequence needed to make slam. Must play according to distribution.

book_title: Dynamic Declarer Play - Virtual European Championship
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Combine technique with psychology - execute double squeeze with psychological chance
solution_line: Win ace of clubs. Check distribution of hearts discarding spade from hand - if four hearts with South, finesse spade (overtake K♦ with ace). If four hearts with North, overtake K♦ with ace and play Q♠. If North does not cover with king, play ace and execute double squeeze for hearts and clubs with North and spades and clubs with South. Of course North did not have to cover with the king and you might down in a slam your granny would have made. Well, it happens.
result_comparison: Contract 6 NT, +990 for Ukraine vs played for double squeeze (+ psychological chance) +11 IMP, if not -14 IMP
additional_notes: North did not have to cover with the king and you might go down in a slam your granny would have made. Well, it happens.
